review.title: Exact and Heuristic Methods for the Assembly Line Worker Assignment and Balancing Problem
review.abstract: In traditional assembly lines, it is reasonable to assume that task execution times are the same for each worker. However, in sheltered work centres for disabled this assumption is not valid: some workers may execute some tasks considerably slower or even be incapable of executing them. Worker heterogeneity leads to a problem called the assembly line worker assignment and balancing problem (ALWABP). For a fixed number of workers the problem is to maximize the production rate of an assembly line by assigning workers to stations and tasks to workers, while satisfying precedence constraints between the tasks. This paper introduces new heuristic and exact methods to solve this problem. We present a new MIP model, propose a novel heuristic algorithm based on beam search, as well as a task-oriented branch-and-bound procedure which uses new reduction rules and lower bounds for solving the problem. Extensive computational tests on a large set of instances show that these methods are effective and improve over existing ones.

sections.heading: 1.1 Problem Definition
sections.text: Let S be a series of stations, W a group of workers, | W | = | S |, and T a series of tasks. Each work station S is placed along a conveyor belt and assigned exactly one worker W ² W, who is responsible for performing a subset of tasks xw ² T. The tasks are partially ordered, and we assume that the partial order is given to the tasks by a transitively reduced steered acyclic graph G (T, E), so that for an arc (t, t ²) no task t ² precedes the task. Therefore, the station executing the task cannot be placed later than task t ² on the conveyor belt. The execution time of task t for the worker w is ptw. If a worker w cannot perform a task t ², ptw is set to task t ². The total execution time of the worker w is Dw = xw ².

sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: The majority of publications on ALWABP-2 are devoted to the use of metaheuristics to find approximate solutions to the problem. Chaves et al. (2007, 2009) proposed two cluster search methods that were largely surpassed by a taboo search by Moreira and Costa (2009). Blum and Miralles (2011) proposed an iterated beam search based on the station-oriented branch-and-bound process by Miralles et al. (2008). Later, Moreira et al. (2012) used constructive heuristics with various combinations of priority rules to find initial solutions for a genetic algorithm (GA). Mutlu et al. (2013) developed an iterated GA that produces valid task orders and uses an iterated local search to assign tasks to the workers in the selected order.

sections.heading: 1.3 Structure of the paper
sections.text: In Section 2, we present a new MIP model for ALWABP-2. In Section 3, we present some lower limits for the problem. In Section 4, a new heuristics for ALWABP-2 is proposed. In Section 5, we present a task-oriented industry and cross-border method for solving the problem. Calculation results are presented and analyzed in Section 6.

sections.heading: 4 Heuristic search procedure
sections.text: In this section we describe a heuristic algorithm IPBS for the ALWABP-2. It systematically searches for a short cycle time by trying to solve the feasibility problem ALWABP-F for different candidate cycle times from an interval that ends at the currently best upper limit.

sections.heading: 4.1 Probabilistic beam search for the ALWABP-F
sections.text: The basis for the probable beam search is a station-based assignment method that assigns tasks from station to station in one procedure. It repeatedly selects an available task for each station until no such task has a execution time less than the idle time of the current station. A task is available if all of its predecessors have already been assigned. If there are several available tasks defined by a priority rule, the task is assigned next. It succeeds when an assignment with a maximum of the available number of stations is found. Station-based procedures can also be applied backwards by assigning tasks whose successors have already been assigned. To do this, it is sufficient to apply a procedure to an instance with reversed dependencies. For ALWABP, we must additionally decide which worker is assigned to the current station. This is achieved by applying the task assignment method to all workers who have not yet been assigned.

sections.heading: 4.3 Improvement by local search
sections.text: A local search is applied to the results found by interval search. It focuses on critical stations whose utilization corresponds to the cycle time of the current assignment. It attempts to remove tasks from a critical station in order to reduce the cycle time. As there may be several critical stations, a train is considered successful if it reduces the number of critical stations. Local search applies the following four types of trains until the assignment can no longer be improved. 1. A shift of a task from one critical station to another station. 2. An exchange of two tasks. At least one of the tasks must be on a critical station. 3. A sequence of two shift trains. Here, the first shift train may produce a worse result than the original assignment. 4. An exchange of workers between two stations without assignment of tasks.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: We have a new MIP model, a heuristic search method, and an exact algorithm for solving the assembly line worker assignment and balancing problem of type 2. The new MIP model demonstrates the importance of incorporating continuity constraints into this type of problem, and its linear loosening provides the current best lower limit for the problem. The proposed heuristic IPBS is competitive with the current best methods, often outperforms them in computation time and quality of solution, and shows robust performance over the entire set of 320 test cases. Finally, the industry-based method can solve cases with a low number of tasks in a few seconds and was able to optimally solve 95 of the 160 cases with a high number of tasks for the first time. In terms of the problem, constraints that force continuity have proven to be the most effective way to strengthen the lower limits in the models, as well as the heuristic and exact algorithm.

Furthermore, the execution of repetitive tasks, when properly assigned, can be an excellent therapeutic treatment for workers with disabilities. Traditional approaches to the optimization of assembly lines assume that the workers have similar abilities and are capable of executing the tasks in the same time. The most basic model of this kind is the Simple Assembly Line Balancing Problem (SALBP), which has been extensively studied in the literature (Scholl and Becker, 2006b). Several authors have considered stochastic models of assembly lines, where task times may vary, and remedial actions are taken if the cycle time is exceeded at some station (Silverman and Carter, 1986; Kottas and Lau, 1976; Lyu, 1997). In this paper we are not directly concerned with varying task times of a single worker, but with the case of SWDs, where the workers need different times to execute the tasks, or may even be incapable of executing some of them. To model such a situation, Miralles et al. (2008) proposed the Assembly Line Worker Assignment and Balancing Problem (ALWABP), which assigns tasks to different workers and these workers to the workstations.
